required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A One-Day ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating
clinical_study.official_title: A One-Day ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating

brief_summary.textblock: Emotional eating is a behaviour that has been linked to weight concerns, mental health concerns, and disordered eating. Effective interventions have been developed to treat emotional eating, however these exist solely in the context of promoting weight loss. Emotional eating is not exclusive to those who struggle with weight and thus interventions are needed that target those who engage in emotional eating regardless of their weight status. The present study aims to do so through the implementation of a one day Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) workshop for emotional eaters.

detailed_description.textblock:
Emotional eating is defined as increased food consumption in response to negative emotions, and has been linked to weight concerns, mental health concerns, and disordered eating behaviours. Effective interventions have been developed that address emotional eating, namely to improve weight loss. Such interventions are based in Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), which encourages tolerance of internal cues, such as emotions, and external cues, such as food.
Emotional eating, however, is not exclusive to those who struggle with their weight. Many individuals maintain a normal weight despite engaging in emotional eating. These individuals still consume an excess of high calorie (for which they somehow eventually compensate), high fat, and high sugar foods as part of their emotional eating. Unhealthy dietary habits such as these have been shown to be associated with an increased risk of all-cause mortality, as well as health concerns including diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Individuals with normal weight are not eligible for ACT programs described above, despite the increased risk of health concerns associated with emotional eating.
The present study aims to test the feasibility and acceptability of a one-day ACT workshop to reduce emotional eating and improve health that is not focused on weight loss as its primary outcome, and rather targets all individuals who engage in emotional eating.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All participants will be assigned to the same intervention.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: Emotional eating, as assessed by the Dutch Eating Behaviour Questionnaire Emotional Eating Subscale (DEBQ-EE). Participants are asked to rate the frequency with which they engage in particular eating behaviours, on a 5-point Likert-type rating scale from never (1) to very often (5), with higher scores reflecting higher emotional eating. Only the emotional eating subscale of the DEBQ will be assessed and is calculated by averaging the 13 items that assess emotional eating.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: Emotional eating, as assessed by the Dutch Eating Behaviour Questionnaire Emotional Eating Subscale (DEBQ-EE). Participants are asked to rate the frequency with which they engage in particular eating behaviours, on a 5-point Likert-type rating scale from never (1) to very often (5), with higher scores reflecting higher emotional eating. Only the emotional eating subscale of the DEBQ will be assessed and is calculated by averaging the 13 items that assess emotional eating.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Distress tolerance, as assessed by the Distress Tolerance Scale (DTS). Participants are asked to indicate the extent to which they agree with statements aimed at assessing distress tolerance, absorption, appraisal, and regulation from 1 (strongly agree) to 5 (strongly disagree), with lower scores reflecting lower distress tolerance. Subscale scores are derived by calculating the means of the items that make up each subscale. Total score is calculating by averaging the four subscales.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Distress tolerance, as assessed by the Distress Tolerance Scale (DTS). Participants are asked to indicate the extent to which they agree with statements aimed at assessing distress tolerance, absorption, appraisal, and regulation from 1 (strongly agree) to 5 (strongly disagree), with lower scores reflecting lower distress tolerance. Subscale scores are derived by calculating the means of the items that make up each subscale. Total score is calculating by averaging the four subscales.

secondary_outcome.measure: Food Craving Acceptance and Action - 2-weeks Post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Food craving acceptance and action, as assessed by the Food Craving Acceptance and Action Questionnaire (FAAQ). Items are rated on a 6-point Likert-type rating scale from 1 (very seldom true) to 6 (always true), with higher scores reflecting higher acceptance. Total score is derived by summing all items. Minimum score is 10 and maximum score is 60.

secondary_outcome.measure: Food Craving Acceptance and Action - 3-months Post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Food craving acceptance and action, as assessed by the Food Craving Acceptance and Action Questionnaire (FAAQ). Items are rated on a 6-point Likert-type rating scale from 1 (very seldom true) to 6 (always true), with higher scores reflecting higher acceptance. Total score is derived by summing all items. Minimum score is 10 and maximum score is 60.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Mindful eating, as assessed by the Mindful Eating Questionnaire (MEQ). It is a 28-item self-report measure that assesses five domains of mindful eating: disinhibition, external cues, awareness, emotional response and distraction. Participants are asked to indicate the extent to which extent they agree with each item from 1 ("never" / "rarely") to 4 ("usually"/ "always"), with higher scores reflecting higher levels of mindful eating. Total score is derived by taking the mean of the five subscales.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Mindful eating, as assessed by the Mindful Eating Questionnaire (MEQ). It is a 28-item self-report measure that assesses five domains of mindful eating: disinhibition, external cues, awareness, emotional response and distraction. Participants are asked to indicate the extent to which extent they agree with each item from 1 ("never" / "rarely") to 4 ("usually"/ "always"), with higher scores reflecting higher levels of mindful eating. Total score is derived by taking the mean of the five subscales.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Application of ACT values techniques taught during the workshop, as assessed by items developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to rate the extent to which they agreed with a number of value-based statements on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Values score was derived by taking the mean of the items, with higher scores reflecting greater value-consistent eating behaviors.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Application of ACT values techniques taught during the workshop, as assessed by items developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to rate the extent to which they agreed with a number of value-based statements on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Values score was derived by taking the mean of the items, with higher scores reflecting greater value-consistent eating behaviors.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: As assessed by a self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of times they engaged in emotional eating in the past week.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: As assessed by a self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of times they engaged in emotional eating in the past week.

secondary_outcome.measure: Ability to Stop Emotional Eating - 2-weeks Post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: As assessed by a single self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of instances in which they began to engage in emotional eating and were able to stop themselves, on a scale from 1 (none of the time) to 5 (very often).

secondary_outcome.measure: Ability to Stop Emotional Eating - 3-months Post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: As assessed by a single self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of instances in which they began to engage in emotional eating and were able to stop themselves, on a scale from 1 (none of the time) to 5 (very often).

secondary_outcome.measure: Feasibility Data: Recruitment, Eligibility, Attendance, and Attrition Rates
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed throughout the duration of the study from the recruitment period to the completion of the workshops and follow-up questionnaires (i.e., over a 3-month period).
secondary_outcome.description: These include recruitment, eligibility, attendance, and attrition rates

arm_group.description: All participants will be assigned to a one-day intervention using Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) techniques to help reduce emotional eating.

intervention.description: This is a one-day intervention using Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) technique to target and reduce emotional eating. The intervention will be modeled after Frayn and Knäuper's (2016) brief emotional eating intervention, which was derived from Forman et al.'s (2013) "Mind Your Health program". During the workshop, the following topics will be discussed, based on the three processes of ACT: (1) values clarification/commitment, (2) acceptance/distress tolerance, and (3) mindfulness/awareness.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Engaging in emotional eating as per a DEBQ-EE score of 3.25 or higher
- Being over the age of 18
Exclusion Criteria:
- Not meeting the DEBQ-EE 3.25 or higher inclusion criteria
- Being under the age of 18

eligibility.gender_description: Intervention is open to all participants regardless of gender identity.

reference.citation: Forman EM, Butryn ML, Juarascio AS, Bradley LE, Lowe MR, Herbert JD, Shaw JA. The mind your health project: a randomized controlled trial of an innovative behavioral treatment for obesity. Obesity (Silver Spring). 2013 Jun;21(6):1119-26. doi: 10.1002/oby.20169. Epub 2013 May 13. Erratum in: Obesity (Silver Spring). 2014 Mar;22(3):971.
Geliebter A, Aversa A. Emotional eating in overweight, normal weight, and underweight individuals. Eat Behav. 2003 Jan;3(4):341-7.

Hou L, Li F, Wang Y, Ou Z, Xu D, Tan W, Dai M. Association between dietary patterns and coronary heart disease: a meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies. Int J Clin Exp Med. 2015 Jan 15;8(1):781-90. eCollection 2015.

Konttinen H, Männistö S, Sarlio-Lähteenkorva S, Silventoinen K, Haukkala A. Emotional eating, depressive symptoms and self-reported food consumption. A population-based study. Appetite. 2010 Jun;54(3):473-9. doi: 10.1016/j.appet.2010.01.014. Epub 2010 Feb 4.

Lillis J, Niemeier HM, Thomas JG, Unick J, Ross KM, Leahey TM, Kendra KE, Dorfman L, Wing RR. A randomized trial of an acceptance-based behavioral intervention for weight loss in people with high internal disinhibition. Obesity (Silver Spring). 2016 Dec;24(12):2509-2514. doi: 10.1002/oby.21680. Epub 2016 Nov 2.
Oliver G, Wardle J, Gibson EL. Stress and food choice: a laboratory study. Psychosom Med. 2000 Nov-Dec;62(6):853-65.

Schwingshackl L, Schwedhelm C, Hoffmann G, Lampousi AM, Knüppel S, Iqbal K, Bechthold A, Schlesinger S, Boeing H. Food groups and risk of all-cause mortality: a systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective studies. Am J Clin Nutr. 2017 Jun;105(6):1462-1473. doi: 10.3945/ajcn.117.153148. Epub 2017 Apr 26. Review.
Sami W, Ansari T, Butt NS, Hamid MRA. Effect of diet on type 2 diabetes mellitus: A review. Int J Health Sci (Qassim). 2017 Apr-Jun;11(2):65-71. Review.

van Strien T, van de Laar FA, van Leeuwe JF, Lucassen PL, van den Hoogen HJ, Rutten GE, van Weel C. The dieting dilemma in patients with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes: does dietary restraint predict weight gain 4 years after diagnosis? Health Psychol. 2007 Jan;26(1):105-12.

patient_data.ipd_description: Study data, including the intervention manual, study protocol, statistical analysis plan, and outcomes will be shared with other researchers upon request.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Upon publication of the study results.

group.title: ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating
group.description: All participants were assigned to an ACT workshop designed to reduce emotional eating through the teaching of three skills: (1) values clarification/commitment, (2) acceptance/distress tolerance, and (3) mindfulness.

group.title: ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating
group.description: All participants were assigned to an ACT workshop designed to reduce emotional eating through the teaching of three skills: (1) values clarification/commitment, (2) acceptance/distress tolerance, and (3) mindfulness.

measure.title: Dutching Eating Behavior Questionnaire-emotional eating
measure.description: Emotional eating, as assessed by the Dutch Eating Behaviour Questionnaire Emotional Eating Subscale (DEBQ-EE). Participants are asked to rate the frequency with which they engage in particular eating behaviours, on a 5-point Likert-type rating scale from never (1) to very often (5), with higher scores reflecting higher emotional eating. Only the emotional eating subscale of the DEBQ will be assessed and is calculated by averaging the 13 items that assess emotional eating.

measure.title: Distress Tolerance Scale
measure.description: Distress tolerance, as assessed by the Distress Tolerance Scale (DTS). Participants are asked to indicate the extent to which they agree with statements aimed at assessing distress tolerance, absorption, appraisal, and regulation from 1 (strongly agree) to 5 (strongly disagree), with lower scores reflecting lower distress tolerance. Subscale scores are derived by calculating the means of the items that make up each subscale. Total score is calculating by averaging the four subscales.

measure.title: Food Craving Acceptance and Action Questionnaire
measure.description: Food craving acceptance and action, as assessed by the Food Craving Acceptance and Action Questionnaire (FAAQ). Items are rated on a 6-point Likert-type rating scale from 1 (very seldom true) to 6 (always true), with higher scores reflecting higher acceptance. Total score is derived by summing all items.

measure.title: Mindful Eating Questionnaire
measure.description: Mindful eating, as assessed by the Mindful Eating Questionnaire (MEQ). It is a 28-item self-report measure that assesses five domains of mindful eating: disinhibition, external cues, awareness, emotional response and distraction. Participants are asked to indicate the extent to which extent they agree with each item from 1 (“never” / “rarely”) to 4 (“usually”/ “always”), with higher scores reflecting higher levels of mindful eating. Total score is derived by taking the mean of the five subscales.

measure.title: ACT Values Application
measure.description: Application of ACT values techniques taught during the workshop, as assessed by items developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to rate the extent to which they agreed with a number of value-based statements on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Values score was derived by taking the mean of the items, with higher scores reflecting greater value-consistent eating behaviors.

measure.title: Emotional eating frequency
measure.description: As assessed by a self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of times they engaged in emotional eating in the past week, from 1 (1 time) to 7 (7 or more times).

measure.title: Ability to stop emotional eating
measure.description: As assessed by a single self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of instances in which they began to engage in emotional eating and were able to stop themselves, on a scale from 1 (none of the time) to 5 (very often).

outcome.title: Emotional Eating - 2-weeks Post-intervention
outcome.description: Emotional eating, as assessed by the Dutch Eating Behaviour Questionnaire Emotional Eating Subscale (DEBQ-EE). Participants are asked to rate the frequency with which they engage in particular eating behaviours, on a 5-point Likert-type rating scale from never (1) to very often (5), with higher scores reflecting higher emotional eating. Only the emotional eating subscale of the DEBQ will be assessed and is calculated by averaging the 13 items that assess emotional eating.
outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
outcome.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

measure.title: Emotional Eating Frequency - 2-weeks Post-intervention
measure.description: As assessed by a self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of times they engaged in emotional eating in the past week.
measure.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

outcome.title: Emotional Eating Frequency - 3-months Post-intervention
outcome.description: As assessed by a self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of times they engaged in emotional eating in the past week.
outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
outcome.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

group.title: ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating
group.description: All participants were assigned to an ACT workshop designed to reduce emotional eating through the teaching of three skills: (1) values clarification/commitment, (2) acceptance/distress tolerance, and (3) mindfulness.

measure.title: Emotional Eating Frequency - 3-months Post-intervention
measure.description: As assessed by a self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of times they engaged in emotional eating in the past week.
measure.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

outcome.title: Ability to Stop Emotional Eating - 2-weeks Post-intervention
outcome.description: As assessed by a single self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of instances in which they began to engage in emotional eating and were able to stop themselves, on a scale from 1 (none of the time) to 5 (very often).
outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
outcome.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

group.title: ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating
group.description: All participants were assigned to an ACT workshop designed to reduce emotional eating through the teaching of three skills: (1) values clarification/commitment, (2) acceptance/distress tolerance, and (3) mindfulness.

measure.description: As assessed by a single self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of instances in which they began to engage in emotional eating and were able to stop themselves, on a scale from 1 (none of the time) to 5 (very often).
measure.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

outcome.time_frame: Assessed from baseline to 2-weeks post-intervention and 3-months post-intervention
outcome.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

measure.description: As assessed by a single self-report item developed by the study's authors. Participants were asked to report the number of instances in which they began to engage in emotional eating and were able to stop themselves, on a scale from 1 (none of the time) to 5 (very often).
measure.population: Based on incomplete questionnaire data, 28/32 participants were included in the final analyses.

outcome.title: Feasibility Data: Recruitment, Eligibility, Attendance, and Attrition Rates
outcome.description: These include recruitment, eligibility, attendance, and attrition rates
outcome.time_frame: Assessed throughout the duration of the study from the recruitment period to the completion of the workshops and follow-up questionnaires (i.e., over a 3-month period).
outcome.population: The population of analysis were the 59 individuals who initially expressed interest in the study.

group.title: ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating
group.description: All participants were assigned to an ACT workshop designed to reduce emotional eating through the teaching of three skills: (1) values clarification/commitment, (2) acceptance/distress tolerance, and (3) mindfulness.

measure.title: Feasibility Data: Recruitment, Eligibility, Attendance, and Attrition Rates
measure.description: These include recruitment, eligibility, attendance, and attrition rates
measure.population: The population of analysis were the 59 individuals who initially expressed interest in the study.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data were collected over the duration that each participant participated in the study (from baseline to 3-months post-intervention).

group.title: ACT Workshop for Emotional Eating
group.description: All participants were assigned to an ACT workshop designed to reduce emotional eating through the teaching of three skills: (1) values clarification/commitment, (2) acceptance/distress tolerance, and (3) mindfulness.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
